That never fail'd her ſervant, glorious war;
For thee, refus'd the fellowſhip of an Order
Which Princes through all dangers have been proud
To fetch as far as from Jeruſalem:
And am I thus rewarded?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: By all goodneſſe,
You wrong my Lady, and deſerve her not,
When you are at your beſt: repent your raſhneſſe,
Twil ſhow well in you.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Do, and aske her pardon.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: No, I have liv'd too long, to have my faith
(My tri'd faith) call'd in queſtion, and by him
That ſhould know true affection is too tender
To ſuffer an unkind touch, without ruine;
Study ingratitude, all, from my example;
For to be thankfull now, is to be falſe.
But be it ſo, let me die, I ſee you wiſh it;
Yet dead for truth, and pities ſake, report
What weapon you made choice of, when you kild me.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: She faints,

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: What have ye done?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: My laſt breath cannot
Be better ſpent, then to ſay I forgive you;
Nor is my death untimely, ſince with me
I take along, what might have been hereafter
In ſcorn delivered for the doubtfull iſſue
Of a ſuſpected mother.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: Oh, ſhe's gone.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: For ever gone. Are you a man?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: I grow here.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Open her mouth, and powre tills Cordiall in it;
If any ſpark of life be unquench'd in her,
This will recover her.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: Tis all in vain,
She's ſtiffe already: live I, and ſhe dead?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: How like a murtherer I ſtand? look up,
And heare me curſe my ſelfe, or but behold
The vengance I wilt take for't Oriana,
And then in peace forſake me: Jealouſie,
Thou loathſome vomit of the fiends below,
What deſperate hunger made me to receive thee
Into my heart, and ſoule? I let thee forth,
And ſo in death finde eaſe; and do's ray fault then
Deſerve no greater puniſhment? no, Ile live
To keep thee for a fury▪ to torment me,
And make me know what hell is on the earth:
All joyes and hopes forſake me; all mens malice,
And all the plagues they can inflict, I wiſh it
Fall thick upon me: Let my teares be laught at,
And may my enemies ſmile to heare me groane,
And dead, may I be pitied of none. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray you ſir why was the Ordnance of the Fort Diſcharg'd ſo ſodainly?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Twas the Governours pleaſure,
In honour of the Dane, a cuſtome us'd,
To ſpeake a Souldiers welcome.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Tis a fit one:
But is my Maſter here too?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Three daies ſince.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Might I demand without offence, ſo much,
Is't pride in him (however now a ſlave)
That I am not admitted to his preſence?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: His curteſie to you, and to mankind
May eaſily reſolve you, he is free
From that poore vice which onely empty men
Eſteem a vertue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What's the reaſon then,
As you imagine, ſir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Why I will tell you;
You are a woman of a tempting beauty,
And he, however vertuous, as a man
Subject to humane frailties; and how far
They may prevaile upon him, ſhould he ſee you,
He is not ignorant: and therefore chooſes,
With care t'avoyd the cauſe that may produce
Some ſtrange effect, which wil not well keep ranck
With the rare temperance, which is admired
In his life hitherto.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This much increaſes
My ſtrong deſire to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: It ſhould rather
Teach you to thank the Prophet that you worſhip,
That you are ſuch a mans, who though he may
Do any thing which youth and heat of blood
Invites him to, yet dares not give way to them:
Your entertainment's Noble, and not like
Your preſent fortune; and it all thoſe teares
Which made grief lovely in you, in the relation
Of the ſad ſtory, that forc'd me to weep too,
Your husbands hard fate were not counterfeit;
You ſhould rejoyce that you have means to pay
A chaſt life to his memory, and bring to him
Thoſe ſweets, which while he liv'd he could not taſte of:
But if you wantonly beſtow them on
Another man, you offer violence
To him, though dead; and his griev'd ſpirit will ſuffer
For your immodeſt looſneſſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why, I hope ſir,
My willingneſſe to looke on him, to whom
I owe my life and ſervice, is no proofe
Of any unchaſt purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: So I wiſh too,
And in the confidence it is not, Lady,
I dare the better tell you he will ſee you
This night, in which by him I am commanded,
To bring you to his chamber; to what end
I eaſily ſhould gueſſe, were I Miranda;
And therefore, though I can yeild liitle reaſon,
(But in a generall love to womens goodneſſe)
Why I ſhould be ſo tender of your honour,
I willingly would beſtow ſome counſaile of you,
And would you follow it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Let me firſt heare it,
And then I can reſolve you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: My advice then
Is, that you would not, (as moſt Ladies uſe
When they prepare themſelves for ſuc encounters)
Study to adde, by artificiall dreſſings
To native excellence; yours (without help)
But ſeen as it is now, would make a Hermit
Leave his deaths head, & change his after hopes
Of endleſſe comforts for a few ſhort minutes
Of preſent pleaſures; to prevent which, Lady,
Practice to take away from your perfections,
And to preſerve your chaſtity unſtain'd,
The moſt deform'd ſhape that you can put on
To cloud your bodies faire gifts, or your minds,
(It being laboured to ſo chaſte an end)
Will prove the faireſt ornament.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To take from
The workmanſhip of Heaven, is an offence
As great, as to endeavour to adde to it;
Of which Ile not be guilty: Chaſtity
That lodges in deformity, appeares rather
A mulct impos'd by nature, then a bleſſing;
And tis commendable onely when it conquers,
Though nere ſo oft aſſaulted, in reſiſtance:
For me, Ile therefore ſo diſpoſe my ſelfe,
That if I hold out, it ſhall be with honour;
Or if I yeeld, Miranda ſhall finde ſomething
To make him love his victory. Exit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: With what cunning
This woman argues for her own damnation?
Nor ſhould I hold it for a miracle,
Since they are all born Sophiſters, to maintaine
That luſt is lawfull, and the end and uſe
Of their creation: would I never had
Hop'd better of her; or could not believe,
Though ſeen the mine, I muſt ever grieve. Exit.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Miranda, Norandine, Servants with lights.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ile ſee you in your chamber. A Table out tow ſtools.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Pray ye no farther:
It is a ceremony I expect not,
I am no ſtranger here, I know my lodging,
And have ſlept ſoundly there, when the Turks Cannon
Playd thick upon't: O 'twas Royall Muſicke,
And to procure a ſound ſleep for a Souldier,
Worth forty of your Fiddles. As you love me
Preſſe it no further.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You will overcome.
Waite on him carefully.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I have tooke ſince ſupper
A rouſe or two too much, and by—
It warms my blood.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You'l ſleep the better for't.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: — on't, I ſhould, had but I a kind wench
To pull my Boot-hoſe off, and warm my night-cap,
There's no charme like it: I love old Adams way;
Give me a diligent Eve, to wait towards bed-time,
Hang up your ſmooth chin page: and now I think on't,
Where is your Turkiſh priſoner?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: In the Caſtle,
But yet I never ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Fie upon you:
See her for ſhame? or, hark ye, if you would
Performe the friends part to me, the friends part,
It being a faſhion of the laſt edition,
Far from panderiſme, now ſend her to me;
You look ſtrange on't, no entertainments perfect
Without it on my word; no livery like it;
Ile tell her, he lookes for it as duly
As for his ſee; there's no ſuit got without it,
Gold is an aſſe to't.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Go to bed, to bed.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Well, if ſhe come, I doubt not to convert her,
If not, the ſin lie on your head.
Good night Exit Nor. and Servants.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: There you ſhall findc hint Lady: you know what I have ſaid,
And if you pleaſe you may make uſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No doubt ſir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: From hence I ſhall heare all.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come hither young one.
Beſhrew my heart, a handſome wench: come neerer,
A very handſome one: doo not you grieve, Sweet,
You are a priſoner?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The loſſe of liberty
No doubt ſir, is a heavy and ſharpe burden
To them that feele it truly: But your ſervant,
Your humble handmayd, never felt that rigor,
Thanks to that Noble wil: no want, no hunger,
(Companions ſtill to ſlaves) no violence,
Nor any unbeſeeming act, we ſtart at,
Have I yet met with; all content and goodneſſe,
Civility, and ſweetneſſe of behaviour
Dwell round about me; therefore, worthy Maſter,
I cannot ſay I grieve my liberty.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Do not you fancieme too cold a Souldier,
Too obſtinate an enemy to youth,
That had ſo faire a Jewell in my Cabinet,
And in ſo long a time, would nere look on it?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What can ſhe ſay now?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sure I deſir'd to ſee ye,
And with a longing wiſh.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: There's all her vertue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Purſu'd that full deſire to give ye thanks ſir,
The onely Sacrifice I have left, and ſervice
For all the vertuous care you have kept me ſafe with.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: She holds well yet.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The pretty foole, ſpeaks finely:
Come ſit down here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O ſir, tis moſt unſeemly.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ile have it ſo: fit cloſe; now tell me truly,
Did you ere love yet?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My yeeres will anſwer that ſir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And did you then love truly?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: So I thought ſir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Can ye love me ſo?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Now!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: With all my duty;
I were unworthy of thoſe favours elſe,
You daily ſhowre upon me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What thinkſt thou of me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I think ye are a truely worthy Gentleman,
A pattern, and a pride to the age ye live in,
Sweet as the commendations all men give ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A pretty flattering rogue; dare ye kiſſe that ſweet man
Ye ſpeak to ſweetly of? Come,

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Farewell vertue.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What haſt thou goe between thy lips? kiſſe once more.
Sure thou haſt a ſpell there.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: More then ere I knew ſir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: All hopes goe now.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I muſt tell you a thing in your eare, and you muſt heare me,
And heare me willingly, and grant me ſo too,
Twill not be worth my asking elſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It muſt be
A very hard thing fir, and from my power,
I ſhall deny your goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Tis a good wench; I muſt lie with ye Lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Tis ſomething ſtrange:
For yet in all my life I knew no bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You will quiekly finde that knowledge.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To what end ſir?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Art thou ſo innocent, thou canſt not gueſſe at it?
Did thy dreams never direct thee?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Faith none yet ſir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ile tell thee then: I would meet thy youth and pleaſure;
Give thee my youth for that, by Heaven ſhe fires me,
And teach thy faire white armes, like wanton Ives,
A thouſand new embraces,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is that all ſir?
And ſay I ſhould try, may not we lie quietly?
Upon my conſcience I could.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: That's as we make it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Grant that, that likes ye beſt, what would ye doe then?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What would I do? certainly, I am no baby,
Nor brought up for a Nun; hark in thine eare.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Fie, fie, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I wold get a brave boy on thee,
A warlike boy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sure we ſhall get ill Chriſtians.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: We'l mend 'em in the breeding then.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sweet Maſter.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Never beliefe in woman come neere me more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My beſt and nobleſt ſir, if a poor Virgin,
(For yet by —I am ſo) ſhould change ſo far
(Seeing your excellence, and able ſweetneſſe)
To forget her ſelfe, and ſlip into your boſome,
Or to your bed, out of a doting on ye,
Take it the beſt way; have you that cruell heart,
That murdring mind too?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes by my troth (Sweet) have I,
To lie with her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And do you think it wel done?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: That's as ſhe'l think when tis done; come to bed wench,
For thou art ſo pretty, and ſo witty a companion,
We muſt not part to night.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Faith let me go ſir,
And think better on't.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Y faith thou ſhalt not;
I warrant thee Ile think on't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have heard 'em ſay here,
You are a mayd too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I am ſure I am, wench,
If that will pleaſe thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have ſeen a wonder,
And would you loſe that for a little wantonneſſe,
(Conſider my ſweet Maſter, like a man, now,)
For a few honied kiſſes, ſleight embraces,
That glory of your youth, that crown of ſweetneſſe?
Can ye deliver that unvalued treaſure?
Would ye forſake, to ſeeke your own diſhonour,
What gone, no age recovers, nor repentance?
To a poore ſtranger?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Hold there again, thou art perfect.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.l: I know you do but try me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And I know
Ile try you a great deale further: prethee to bed;
I love thee, and ſo well: come kiſſe me once more;
Is a maidenhead ill beſtow'd o' me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What's this ſir?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why, tis the badge (my Sweet) of that holy Order
I ſhortly muſt receive, the Croſſe of Malta.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What vertue has it?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: All that we call vertuous.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Who gave it firſt?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: He that gave all, to ſave us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why then tis holy too?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: True ſign of holineſſe,
The badge of all his Souldiers that profeſſe him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The badge of all his ſouldiers that profeſſe him,
Can ſave in dangers?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: In troubles comfort?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You ſay true, ſweet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: In ſickneſſe, reſtore health?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: All this it can do.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Preſerve from evils, that afflict our frailties.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I hope ſhe will be Chriſtian: all theſe truly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why are you ſick then, ſick to death with luſt?
In danger to be loſt? no holy thought,
ln all that heart, nothing but wandring frailties
Wild as the wind, and blind as death or ignorance,
Inhabit there.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Forgive me heaven, ſhe ſayes true.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Dare ye profeſſe that badg, prophan that goodnes?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Thou haſt redeemd thy ſelf again, moſt rarely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That holines and truth ye make me wonder at?
Blaſt all the bounty heaven gives, that remembrance.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: O excellent woman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Fling it from ye quickly,
If ye be thus reſolu'd; I ſee a vertue
Appear in't like a ſword, both edges flaming
That wil conſum ye, and your thoughts, to aſhes,
Let them profeſſe it that are pure, and noble,
Gentle, and juſt of thought, that build the croſſe,
Not thoſe that break it, by—if ye touch me,
Even in the act, ile make that croſſe, and curſe ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You ſhall not (fair) I did diſſemble with ye,
And but to try your faith, I faſhioned all this:
Yet ſomething you provoakt me: this fair croſſe,
By me (if he but pleaſe to help, firſt gave it)
Shall ne'r be worne upon a heart corrupted;
Go to your reſt, my modeſt, honeſt ſervant,
My fair, and vertuous maid, and ſleep ſecure there,
For when you ſuffer, I forget this ſigne here.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A man of men too: O moſt perfect Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: All ſweet reſt to your ſir; I am halfe a Chriſtian,
The other half, i'le pray for; then for you, ſir;

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This is the fowleſt play i'le ſhew, good night, ſweet.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: The Sun's not ſet yet?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Would it were,
Never to riſe againe to light the world.
And yet, to what vaine purpoſe do I wiſh it,
Since though I were inviron'd with thick miſts,
Black as Cymerian darkneſſe, or my crimes,
There is that here, upon which, as an anvile
Ten thouſand hammers ſtrike, and every ſpark
They force from it, to me's an other Sun
To light me to my ſhame?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Take hope, and comfort.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: They are aides indeed, but yet as far from me,
As I from being innocent: this cave faſhioned
By provident nature, in this ſolid Rock
To be a den for beaſts, alone, receives me,
And having prov'd an enemy to mankinde,
All humane helpes forſak me.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: I'le ne'r leave you,
And wiſh you would call back that noble courage
That old invicible fortitude of yours
That us'd to ſhrink at nothing.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Then it did not.
But 'twas when I was honeſt; then in the height
Of all my hapineſſe, of all my glories,
Of all delights, that made life pretious to me,
I durſt die Rocca; death it ſelf then to me
Was nothing terrible, becauſe I knew,
The fame of a good Knight woulde ever live
Freſh on my memory; but ſince I fell
From my integrity, and diſmis'd thoſe guards,
Thoſe ſtrong aſſurances of innocence,
That conſtancy fled fron me, and what's worſe,
Now I am loathſome to my ſelf; and life
A burthen to me, rackd with ſad remembrance
Of what I have done, and my preſent horrors
Unſufferable to me, torturd with deſpair
That I ſhall ne'r find mercy; hell about me,
Behind me, and before me, yet I dare not
Still fearing worſe, put off my wretched being. Enter Abdella

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: To ſee this would deterre a doubtfull man
From miſcheivous intents, much more the practiſe
Of what is wicked: here's the Moore, look up ſir,
Some eaſe may come from her.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: New trouble rather,
And I expect it.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Who is this? Mountferrat?
Riſe up for ſhame, and like a river dride up
With a long drought, from me, your bounteous Sea
Receive thoſe tides of comfort, that flow to you;
If ever I lookt lovely, if deſert
Could ever challenge welcom; if revenge,
And unexpected wreak, were ever pleaſing
Or could endear the giver of ſuch bleſſings,
All theſe I come adorn'd with, and as due
Make challenge of thoſe ſo long wiſhd embraces
Which you (unkind) have hitherto denyde me.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Why, what have you done for me?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Made Gomera
As truly miſerable, as you thought him happy,
Could you wiſh more?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As if his ſickneſſe could
Recover me; the injuries I received
Were Orianas.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: She has paid deer for them,
She's dead.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Dead: my hate could reach no further:
Taking advantage of her in a ſwoon,
Under pretence to give a Cordiall to her
I poyſond her: what ſtupid dulneſſe is this?
What you ſhould entertain with ſacrifice,
Can you receive ſo coldly?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Bloody deeds
Are gratefull offrings, pleaſing to the devill,
And thou, in thy black ſhape, and blacker actions
Being hels perfect character, art delighted
To do what I though infinitly wicked,
Tremble to hear: thou haſt in this tane from me
All meanes to make amends with penitence,
To her wrongd vertues, and diſpoild me of
The poor remainder of that hope was left me,
For all I have already, or muſt ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: I did it for the beſt.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: For thy worſt ends,
And be aſſurd, but that, I think to kill thee
Would but prevent, what thy deſpair muſt force thee
To do unto thy ſelf, and ſo to adde to
Thy moſt aſſur'd damnation, thou went dead now,
But get thee from my ſight: and if luſt of me
Did ever fire thee (love, I cannot call it)
Leap down from thoſe ſteep Rocks, or take advantage
Of the next Tree, to hang thy ſelf, and then
I may laugh at it.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: In the mean time
I muſt be bold, to do ſo much for you, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mount,
sp.l: Why grinſt thou, devill?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: That 'tis in my power,
To puniſh thy ingratiude; I made triall
But how you ſtood affected, and ſince I know
I am us'd only for a property,
I can, and will revenge it to the full.
For, underſtand, in thy contempt of me
Thoſe hopes of Oriana, which I could
Have changd to certainties, are loſt for ever.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Why, lives ſhe?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Yes, but never to Mountf●rrat,
Although it is in me, with as much eaſe
To give her freely up to thy poſſeſſion,
As to remove this ruſh, which yet deſpaire of,
For by my much wrongd love, flattery, nor threats,
Teares, prayers, nor vowes, ſhall ever win me to it:
So with my curſe, I leave thee.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Prethee ſtay,
Thou knowſt'I doat on thee, and yet thou art
So peeviſh, and perverſe, ſo apt to take
Triffles unkindly from me.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: To perſwade me
To break my neck, to hang, then damn my ſelf,
With you are trifles.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: 'T was my melancholy
That made me ſpeak I know not what: forgive,
I will redem my fault.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Believe him Lady.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: A thouſand times I will demand thy pardon,
And keep the reckoning on thy lips, with kiſſes.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Ther's ſomething els, that would prevaile more with me.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt have all thy wiſhes do but bleſſe me
With meanes to ſatisfie my madde deſires
For once in Oriana, and for ever
I am thine, only thine my beſt Abdella.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Were I aſſur'd of this, and that you would
Having enioyd her.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Any thing: make choice of
Thine own conditions.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Swear then, that performed.
(To free me from all doubts and fears hereafter)
To give me leave to kill her.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: That our ſafety
Muſt of neceſſity urge us to.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Then know
It was not poyſon, but a ſleeping potion
Which ſhe received, yet of ſufficient ſtrength
So to bind up her ſences, that no ſigne
Of life appeard in her, and thus thought dead
In her beſt habit, as the cuſtome is
You know in Malta, with all ceremonies
She's buried in her families monument,
In the Temple of St. Iohn; i'le bring you thither,
Thus, as you are diſguiſd; ſome ſix howers hence
The potion will leave working.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Let us haſte then. Diſcover Tombe

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Be my good angel, guid me.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: But remember
You keep your Oath.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As I deſire to proſper
In what I undertak.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: I ask no more. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Here ſir, I have got the Key, I borrowd it
Of him that keeps the Church, the door is open.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Look to the horſes then, and pleaſe the fellow.
After a few devotions, i'le retire.
Be not far off, there may be ſome uſe of ye,
Give me the light: come friend, a few good prayers
Were not beſtowd in vaine now, even from you ſir.
Men that are bred in blood, have no way left 'em,
No bath, no purge, no time to weare it out
Or waſh it off, but penitence, and prayer:
I am to take the order, and my youth
Loaden I muſt confeſſe with many follies,
Circled and bound about with ſins as many
As in the houſe of memory live figures.
My heart i'le open now, my faults confeſſe.
And riſe a new man, heaven I hope, to a new life.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I have no great devotion, at this inſtant,
But for a prayer or two, I will not out ſir,
Hold up your finger, when you have praid enough.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Go you to that end.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I ſhall ne'r pray alone ſure,
sp.p: I have bin ſo us'd to anſwer the Clerk: would I had a cuſhion, for I ſhall ne'r make a good Hermit, and knee till my knees are horn, theſe ſtones are plaguy hard where ſhal I begin now? for if I do not obſerve a method, I ſhall be out preſently.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Whats that ſir? did ye heare?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ha; to your prayers.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: 'Twas here abouts, t'has put me clean awry now,
I ſhall ne'r get in again, ha, by Land,
And water, all children, and all women,
I there it was I left.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Never tell me ſir,
Here's ſomething got amongſt us.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I heard a groane:
A diſmall one,—Ori. Oh, Oh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Here, tis here ſir, 'tis here ſir;
A devill in the wall.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Tis ſome illuſion
To fright us from devotion—Ori. Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Why tis here,
The ſpirit of a hunteſman choakd with butter,
Her's a new tomb, new trickments too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: For certaine,
This has not bin three dayes here.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: And a Tablet
With rimes upon't.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I prethee read 'em Norandine.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: An Epi—and Epi—taff. I think 'tis, I 'tis taff, an Epitaff.
Upon the moſt excell, excell—lent—and.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thou canſt not read.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I have ſpoild imine eyes with gunpowder,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: An Epitaph upon the moſt vertuous, and excellent Lady
The honor of Chaſtity, Oriana.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: The grand maſters ſiſter: how a devil came ſhe here?
When ſlipt ſhe out oth'way, the ſtone's but half upon her.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Tis is a ſodain chang: certain the miſchiefe
Mountferrat offerd to her broak her heart-ſtrings.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Would he were here, I would be the clerk my ſelf,
And by this little light. I would bury him alive here,
Her's no lamenting now.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: There tis.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sure from the monument, the very ſtone groanes for her.
Oh, deer Lady: bleſſing of women, vertue of thy ſex;
How art thou ſet for ever, how ſtolne from us.
Babling, and prating now converſe with women.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Sir it riſes, it looks up. She riſes up.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Heaven bleſſe us.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: It is in womans cloathes, it riſes higher.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: It looks about, and wonders, ſure ſhe lives ſir.
Tis ſhe, tis Oriana, tis that Lady.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Shall I go to her?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Where am I!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Stand ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: What place is this?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: She is as live as I am.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: What ſinell of earth, and rotten bones, what dark place.
Lord, whether am I carried?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: How ſhe ſtares,
And ſets her eyes upon him.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How is't deer Lady?
Do you know me, how ſhe ſhakes?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: You are a man.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A man that honours you.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: A cruell man,
Ye are all cruell: are you in your grave too?
For ther's no truſting cruell man, above ground.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Byr' Lady, that goes hard.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: To do your ſervice
And to reſtore ye to the joyes you were in.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I was in joyes indeed, and hope—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: She ſincks againe
Again ſhe is gon; ſhe is gon: gon as a ſhadow,
She ſinks for ever, friend.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: She is cold now,
She is certainly departed, I muſt cry too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The bleſſed angels guide thee: put the ſtone too,
Beauty thou art gon to duſt, goodneſſe to aſhes.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Pray take it well: we muſt all have our houres ſir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I, thus we are; and all our painted glory,
A buble that a boy blowes in toth' ayre,
And there it breaks.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I am glad ye ſav'd her honour yet.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Would I had ſav'd her life now too: oh heaven
For ſuch a bleſſing, ſuch a timely bleſſing
O friend, what deer content 't would be, what ſtory
To keep my name from wormes?

sp.speaker: Oria
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: She lives again,
'Twas but a trance.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Pray ye call my man in preſently
Help with the ſtone firſt, oh ſhe ſtirs againe.
Oh call my man away.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I fly, I fly ſir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Upon my knees O heaven, O heaven I thank thee. The living heat ſteales into every member; En. Colonn. & Come help the Coffin out, ſoftly, and ſodainly Norand. VVhere is the Clerk?.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Drunk above, he is ſure ſir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sirah, you muſt be ſecret.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: As your ſoule ſir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Softly good friend, take her into your armes.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Put in the cruſt againe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And bring her out there when I am a horſeback
My man, and I will tenderly conduct her
Unto the Fort; ſlay you, and watch what iſſue,
And what inquirie's for the body.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Well ſir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And when ye have done, come back to me.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Softly, oh ſoftly.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: She growes warmer ſtill ſir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What ſhall I do with' Key?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thou canſt not ſtir now,
Leave it ith' door: go get the horſes ready. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: The door's already open, the Key in it. En. Rocca Mountferrat Abdella. With a dark lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: What were thoſe paſt by?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Some ſcout of Souldiers, I think.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: It may be well ſo, for I ſaw their horſes,
They ſaw not us I hope.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: No, no, we were cloſe,
Beſide they were far off.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: What time of night is't?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Much about twelve I think.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Let me go in firſt
For by the leaving open of the door here
There may be ſome body in the Church: give me the Lanthorne.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: You'l love me now I hope.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Make that good to me
Your promiſe is engaged for.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Why ſhe is there
Ready prepar'd, and much about this time
Life will look up again.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Come in all's ſure,
Not a foot ſtirring, nor a tongue.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Heaven bleſſe me,
I never enter'd with ſuch unholy thoughts
This place before.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Ye are a fearfull foole,
If men have appetites allow'd 'em,
And warm deſires, are there not ends too for 'em?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Whether ſhall we carry her?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Why, to the bark, ſir,
I have provided one already waites us
The wind ſtands wondtrous fair too for our paſſge.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: And there, when ye'have enjoyd her, for ye have that liberty
Let me alone to ſend her to feed fiſhes,
I'le no more ſighes for her.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Where is the monument?
Thou art ſure ſhe will awake about this time?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Moſt ſure, If ſhe be not knockt oth'head: give me the Lanthorn,
Here 'tis, how is this, the ſtone off?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: I, and nothing
Within the monument, that's worſe, no body
I am ſure of that, nor ſigne of any here,
But an empty Coffin.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: No Lady.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: No, nor Lord ſir,
This Pye has bin cut up before.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Either the Devill
Muſt doe theſe tricks—

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Or thou, damn'd one, worſe;
Thou black ſwoln pitchie cloud, of all my afflictions:
Thou night hag, gotten when the bright Moone ſufferd
Thou hell it ſelf confin'd in fleſh: what trick now?
Tell me, and tell me quickly what thy miſchief
Has done with her, and to what end, and whether
Thou haſt remov'd her body, or by this holy place
This ſword ſhall cut thee into thouſand peeces.
A thouſand thouſand, ſtrow thee ore the Temple
A ſacrifice to thy black ſire, the Devill.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Tell him, you ſee he's angry.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Let him burſt,
Neither his ſword, nor anger do I ſhake at,
Nor will yeild to feed his poor ſuſpitions,
His idle jealouzies, and madde dogs heares
One thought againſt my ſelf: ye have done a brave deed
A manly, and a valiant peece of Service
When ye have kill'd me; reckon't amongſt your Battels:
I am ſorry ye are ſo poore, ſo weake a gentleman
Able to ſtand no fortune: I diſpoſe of her?
My miſchiefe make her away? a likely project,
I muſt play booty againſt my ſelfe, if any thing croſſe ye
I am the devill, and the devils heire,
All plagues, all miſchiefes.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Will I ye leave and doe yet?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I have done too much,
For, far too much for ſuch a thankleſſe fellow,
If I be devill, you created me,
I never knew thoſe arts, nor bloody practiſes
(— o' your cunning heart, that mine of miſchiefe)
Before your flatteries won 'em into me,
Here did I leave her, leave her with that certainty
About this houre to wake again.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Where is ſhe?
This is the laſt demand.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Did I now know it,
And were I ſure, this were my lateſt minute
I would not tell thee: ſtrike, and then i'le curſe thee:

sp.speaker: Rocca
sp.l: I ſee a light, ſtand cloſe, and leave your angers.
We all miſcarry elſe. Enter Gomera, Page with Torch.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I am now careleſſe,

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Peace, prethee peace, ſweet, peace, all friends,

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Stand cloſe then.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Waite there Boy, with the light, till I call to thee,
In darkneſſe was my ſoule and ſences clouded
When my faire Jewell fell, the night of jealouſie,
In all her blackneſſe drawn about my judgement:
No light was let into me: to diſtinguiſh
Betwixt my ſuddain anger and her honour,
A blinde ſad Pilgrimage ſhall be my pennance,
No comfort of the day will I looke up at:
Far darker then my jealous Ignorance
Each place of my aboad ſhall do my: prayers
No ceremonious lights ſhall ſet off more;
Bright Armes, and all that carry luſtre, life,
Society, and ſollace, I forſake ye.
And were it not once more to ſee her beauties
(For in her bed of death, ſhe muſt be ſweet ſtill,)
And on her cold ſad lips ſeal my repentance;
Thou child of heaven, faire light I could not miſſe thee.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: I know the tongue, would I were out againe I have done him too much wrong to looke upon him.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: There is no ſhifting now, boldneſſe, and confidence
Muſt carry it now away: he is but one neither,
Naked as you are, of a ſtrength far under

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: But he has a cauſe above me,

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: That's as you handle it.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Peace: he may goe againe, and never ſee us.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: I feele I weepe apace, but where's the flood,
The torrent of my teares, to drown my fault in,
I would I could now like a loaden cloud
Begotten in the moyſt ſouth, drop to nothing
Give me the Torch, Boy.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Now he muſt diſcover us.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: He has already, never hide your head
Be bold, and brave, if we muſt dye together.

sp.speaker: Gom:
sp.l: Who's there? what friend to ſorrow? The Tombe wide open
The Stone off too? the body gone, by —
Looke to the doore Boy: keep it faſt, who are ye?
What ſacrilegious villaines? falſe Mountferrat,
The wolfe to honour, has thy helliſh hunger,
Brought thee to tear the body out oth'tomb too?
Has thy foule mind ſo far wrought on thee? ha,
Are you there too? nay, then I ſpie a villany
I never dream't of yet, thou ſinfull uſher
Bred from that rottenneſſe, thou bawd to miſchiefe,
Doe you bluſh through all your blackneſſe? will not that hide it?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I cannot ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: You are well met, with your dam, ſir,
Art thou a Knight? did ever on that ſword,
The Chriſtian cauſe ſit nobly? could that hand fight,
Guided by fame, and fortune? that heart inflame thee,
With vertuous fires of valour, to fall off,
Fall off ſo ſuddainly, and with ſuch fouleneſſe,
As the falſe Angels did, from all their glory?
Thou art no Knight, honour thou never heard'ſt of,
Nor brave deſires could ever build in that breaſt,
Treaſon, and tainted thoughts, are all the Gods
Thou worſhip'ſt, all the ſtrength thou hadſt: and fortune;
Thou didſt things out of feare, and falſe heart, villaine
Out of cloſe traps and treacheries, they have rais'd thee.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Thon rav'ſt old man.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Before thou get'ſt off from me,
Had'ſt thou the glory of thy firſt fights on thee
Which thou haſt baſely loſt, thy nobleſt fortunes,
And in their greateſt luſtres, I would make thee
Before we part, confeſſe, nay, kneele, and doe it,
Nay, crying kneele, coldly for mercy, crying:
Thou art the recreant'ſt Rogue, time ever nouriſh'd,
Thou art a dogge, I will make thee ſweare, a dog ſtav'd,
A mangy Cur-dogge; doe you creep behind the Altar?
Looke how it ſweats, to ſhelter ſuch a raſcall;
Firſt, with thy venemous tooth infect her chaſte life,
And then not dare to doe; next, rob her reſt,
Steale her dead body out oth' grave.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I have not.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Prethee come out, this is no place to quarrell in, Valiant Mountferrat come,

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I will not ſtir.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Thou haſt thy ſword about thee,
That good ſword, that never fail'd thee: prethee come,
We'l have but five ſtroakes for it, on, on Boy,
Here's one would faine be acquainted with thee,
Would wondrous fain cleave that Calves-head of yours ſir,
Come, prethee let's diſpatch, the Moone ſhines finely:
Prethee be kill'd by me, thou wilt be hang'd elſe,
But it may be, thou long'ſt to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Out with him, Sir,
You ſhall have my ſword too: when he's diſpatch'd once
We have the world before us.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Wilt thou walke fellow,
I never knew a Rogue, hang arſe-ward ſo,
And ſuch a deſperate knave too.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Pray goe with him,
Something I'le promiſe too,

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: You would be kill'd then?
No remedy; I ſee,

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: If thou dar'ſt doe it?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Yes, now I dare; lead out, i'le follow preſently Vnder the Mount i'le meet ye.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Goe before me,
He have ye in a ſtring too.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As I am a Gentleman,
And by this holy place, I will not faile thee,
Feare not, thou ſhalt be kill'd, take my word for it
I will not faile.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: If thou ſeap'ſt thou haſt Cats luck,
The Mount?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: The ſame: make haſte, I am there before elſe.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Goe get ye home; now if he ſcape I am Cowar'd.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Well, now I am reſolv'd, and he ſhall finde it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How is it with the Lady?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, as well
As it can be with one, who feeling knowes now
What is the curſe the divine juſtice lay'd
On the firſt ſinfull woman.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Is ſhe in travell?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yes ſir; and yet the troubles of her mind
Afflict her more, then what her body ſuffers,
For in the extremity of her paine, ſhe cries out,
Why am I here? Where is my Lord Gomera,
Then ſometimes names Miranda, and then ſighes,
As if to ſpeake, what queſtionleſſe ſhe loves well,
If heard, might doe her injury.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Heavens ſweet mercy
Looke gently on her,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Prethee tell her, my Prayers
Are preſent with her, and good wench provide
That ſhe want nothing: what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Lucinda? there's a proſperous omen in it,
Bea Lucina to her, and bring word
That ſhe is ſafe delivered of her burthen,
And thy rewards thy liberty: come Collonna,
We will goe ſee how th' Engineer has mounted
The Canon the great Maſter ſent, be carefull.
To view the workes, and learn the diſcipline
That is us'd here: I am to leave the world
And for your ſervice, which I have found faithfull.
The charge that's mine, if I have any power
Hereafter may concerne you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I ſtill finde
A noble Maſter in you,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis but juſtice,
sp.p: Thou do'ſt deſerve it in thy care, and duty. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Gomera, Mountferrat, Rocca, Abdella, with a Piſtoll.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Here's even ground, i'le ſtir no foot beyond it, Before I have thy head.

sp.speaker: Maunt.
sp.l: Draw Rocca.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Coward,
Hath inward guilt, rob'd thee as well of courage
As honeſty? that without oddes thou dar'ſt not
Anſwer a ſingle Enemy?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: All advantage
That I can take, expect.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: We know you are valiant,
Nor doe we purpoſe to make further triall
Of what you can doe now: but to diſpatch you.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: And therefore fight, and pray together.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Villaines,
Whoſe baſeneſſe, all diſgracefull words made one,
Cannot expreſſe; ſo ſtrong is the good cauſe
That ſeconds me, that you ſhall feele, with horrour
To your proud hopes, what ſtrength is in that arme,
Though old, that holds a ſwor made ſharp by juſtice.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: You come then here, to prate? fight.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Helpe Rocca, now,
Or I am loſt forever; how comes this?
Are villany, and weakneſſe twynes?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: I am gone too.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: You ſhall not ſcape me, wretches,

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I muſt doe it,
All will goe wrong elſe. ſhoots him

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Treacherous bloody woman,
What haſt thou done?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Done a poor womans part,
And in an inſtant, what theſe men ſo long
Stood fooling for.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: This aide was unexpected,
I kiſſe thee for't,

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: His right armes onely ſhot,
And that compell'd him to forſake his ſword,
He's elſe unwounded.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Forbeare.
Yet doe not hope 'tis with intent to ſave thee.
But that thou maiſt live to thy farther torment
To ſee who triumphes over thee: come Mountferrat,
Here joyne thy foot to mine, and let our hearts
Meet with our hands, the contract that is made
And cemented with blood, as this of ours is,
Is a more holy ſanction, and much ſurer,
Then all the ſuperſtitious ceremonies Enter Norandine.
You Chriſtians uſe.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Who's this?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Betray'd againe?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: By the report it made, and by the wind
The Piſtoll was diſcharged here.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: As ever thou lov'ſt valour, or wear'ſt Armes
To puniſh baſeneſſe, ſhew it.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: O the devill,
Gomera wounded, and my Brache black beauty
An actor in it?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: If thou ſtrik'ſt, i'le ſhoot thee.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: How? fright me with your Pot-gun? what art thou?
Good heaven, the Rogue, the traytor rogue Mountferrat
To ſwinge the neaſt of you, is a ſport unlook'd for,
Hels— conſume you.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As thou art a man;
I am wounded, give me time to anſwer thee.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Durſt thou urge this? this hand can hold a ſword yet.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Well done: to ſee this villaine, makes my hurts
Bleed freſh againe, but had I not a bone whole,
In ſuch a cauſe I ſhould doe thus, thus Raſcals. Enter Corporall and watch.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Diſarme them, and ſhoot any that reſiſts.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Hold Corporall; I am Gomera,

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Tis well yet, that once in an age you can
Remember what you watch for; I had thought
You had again been making out your parties
For ſucking piggs.
'Tis well:

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: As you will anſwer
The contrary with your lives, ſee theſe forth coming.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: That we ſhall doe.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: You bleed a pace: good Souldiers
Goe helpe him to a Surgeon,

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Dare the worſt,
And ſusser like your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: From me learne courage.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Now for Miranda, this newes will be to him
As welcome, as 'tis unexpected: Corporall,
There's ſomething for thy care to night: my horſe there.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: How do's my Boy?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Oh, wondrous luſty, Madam,
A little Knight already: you ſhall live
To ſee him toſſe a Turke.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Gentle Lucinda,
Much muſt I thank thee for thy care, and ſervice.
And may I grow but ſtrong to ſee Ʋaletta, Enter Miranda, Norandine, Collonna.
My husband, and my brother, thou ſhalt finde
I will not barely thank thee.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Looke Captaine, we muſt ride away this mornning
The Auberge ſits to day, and the great Maſter
Writes plainly, I muſt or deliver in
(The yeere expir'd) my probation weed,
Or take the Cloake: you likewiſe Norandine
For your full ſervice, and your laſt aſſiſtance
In falſe Mountferrats apprehenſion
Are here commanded to aſſociate me; my twin in this high honour.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Ile none on't: doe they think to bind me to live chaſte, ſober, and temperately, all dayes of my life? they may as ſoone tye an Engliſhman to live ſo: I ſhall be a ſweet Dane, a ſweet Captaine, goe up and downe drinking ſmall beere, and ſwearing odds neagues; no Ile live a Squire at Armes ſtill, and doe thou ſo too; and thou beeſt wiſe: I have found the myſtery now, why the Gentlemen weare but three barres of the croſſe, and the knights the whole one.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why Captaine?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Mary ſir, to put us in remembrance, we are but three quarters croſs'd in our licence, and pleaſures: but the poore Knights croſs'd altogther; the brothers at Armes, may yet meet with their Siſters at Armes, now and then, in brotherly love; but the poore Knights can|not get a Lady for love, nor money: 'tis not ſo in other Countries I wis, pray haſte you, for i'le along, and ſee what will come on't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Collonna, provide ſtrait, all neceſſaries
For this remove, the Lytter for the Lady,
And let Lucinda beare her company,
You ſhall attend on me.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: With all my duties Exit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How fare you, gracious Miſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: O Miranda.
You pleas'd to honour me with that faire title
When I was free, and could diſpoſe my ſelfe;
But now, no ſmile, no word, no looke, no touch
Can I impart to any, but as theft
From my Gomera; and who dares accept,
Is an unſurper.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Leave us; I have touch'd thee,
(Thou fairer vertue, then thou'rt beautifull)
Hold but this teſt, ſo rich an one was never Altar ready, Tapers & booke
Try'd by the hand of man, on the vaſt earth:
Sit brighteſt Oriana, is it ſinne
Still to profeſſe I love you, ſtill to vow
I ſhall doe ever? heaven my witneſſe be,
'Tis not your eye, your cheeke, your tongue, no part
That ſuperficially doth ſnare young men,
Which has caught me; read over in your thoughts
The ſtory that this man hath made of you,
And thinke upon his merit.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Onely thought
Can comprehend it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And can you be ſo
Cruell, thankeleſſe, to deſtroy his youth
That ſav'd your honour, gave you double life?
Your own, and your faire Infants? that when fortune
(The blind foe to all beauty, that is good,)
Bandied you from one hazard to another,
Was even heavens Meſſenger, by providence
Call'd to the Temple, to receive you there,
Into theſe Armes, to give eaſe to your throwes,
As if't had thunder'd; take thy due Miranda,
For ſhe was thine; Gomera's jealouſie
Strooke death unto thy heart; to him be dead,
And live to me, that gave thee ſecond life:
Let me but now enjoy thee: Oh regard
The torturing fires of my affections.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Oh maſter them, Miranda, as I mine;
Who follows his deſires, ſuch tyrants ſerves
As will oppreſſe him, inſupportably.
My flames, Miranda, riſe as high as thine,
For I did love thee 'fore my marriage,
Yet would I now conſent, or could I think
Thou wert in earneſt, (which by all the ſoules
That have (for chaſtity) been ſanctified
I cannot) in a moment I doe know
Thou'ldſt call faire temperance up to rule thy blood,
Thy eye was ever chaſte, thy countenance too honeſt,
And all thy woings was like maidens talk;
Who yeeldeth unto pleaſures, and to luſt
Is a poore captive, that in Golden Fetters
(And pretious (as he thinkes) but holding gyves)
Frets out his life.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Find ſuch another woman,
And take her for his labour, any man:

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I was not worthy of thee, at my beſt,
Heaven knew I was not, I had had thee elſe;
Much leſſe now gentle ſir; Mirandas deeds
Have been as white, as Orianas fame,
From the beginning, to this point of time,
And ſhall we now begin to ſtaine both thus?
Think on the legend which we two ſhall breed
Continuing as we are, for chaſteſt dames
And boldeſt Souldiers to peruſe and read,
I and read thorough, free from any act
To cauſe the modeſt caſt the booke away,
And the moſt honour'd Captaine fold it up.

sp.speaker: Mir;
sp.l: Faireſt; let goe my hand: my pulſe beats thick,
And my mov'd blood rides high in every vaine,
Lord of thy ſelfe now, Souldier, and ever:
I would not for Aleppo, this fraile Bark,
This barke of fleſh, no better fleeres-man had
Then has Mountferrat's: may you kiſſe me, Lady?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: No; though't be no eſſentiall injury,
It is a circumſtance due to my Lord,
To none elſe: and my deereſt friend, if hands
Playing together, kindle heate in you,
What may the game at lips provoke unto?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Oh what a tongue is here? whil'ſt ſhe doth teach
My heart to hate my fond unlawfull love,
She talkes me more in love, with love to her,
My fires ſhe quencheth with her arguments,
But as ſhe breathes 'em, they blow freſher fires.
Sir further: now my flame cooles; husband, wife,
There is ſome holy myſtery in thoſe names
That ſure the unmarried cannot underſtand.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Now thou art ſtrait, and do'ſt enamour me,
So far beyhnd a carnall earthly love;
My very ſoule doats on thee, and my ſpirits
Doe embrace thine, my minde doth thy mind kiſſe,
And in this pure conjunction we enjoy
A heavenlyer pleaſure then if bodies met:
This, this is perfect love, the other ſhort,
Yet languiſhing fruition, every Swaine
And ſweating Groome may claſp, but our's refinde
Two in ten ages cannot reach unto;
Nor is our ſpirituall love, a barren joy,
For mark what bleſſed iſſue we'll beget,
Deerer then children to poſterity,
A great example to mens continence,
And womens chaſtity, that is a childe
More faire, and comfortable, then any heire.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: If all wives were but ſuch, luſt would not finde
One corner to inhabit, ſinne would be
So ſtrange, remiſſion ſuperfluous:
But one petition, I have done.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: What (Sweet?).

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: To call me Lord, if the hard hand of death ſeize on Gomera firſt.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Oh, much too worthy;
How much you undervalue your own price,
To give your unbought ſelfe, for a poore woman,
That has been once ſold, us'd, and loſt her ſhow?
I am a garment worne, a veſſell crack'd,
A zoane untide, a Lilly trod upon,
A fragrant flowre cropt by anothers hand,
My colour ſullyde, and my odour chang'd,
If when I was new bloſſom'd, I did feare
My ſelfe unworthy of Mirandas ſpring:
Thus over-blown, and ſeeded, I am rather
Fit to adorn his Chimney, then his bed.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Riſe miracle: ſave Malta, with thy vertue,
If words could make me proud, how has ſhe ſpoke,
Yet I will try her to the very block:
Hard-hearted, and uncivill Oriana,
Ingratefull payer of my induſtries,
That with a ſoft painted hypocriſie
Cozen'ſt, and geer'ſt my perturbation,
Expect a witty, and a fell revenge:
My comfort is, all men will thinke thee falſe,
Beſide thy husband having been thus long Enter Nor. Collonna & Lucinda with a Childe.
(on this occaſion) in my Fort, and power.
Ile heare no more words: Captaine, let's away
With all care ſee to her: and you Lucinda
Attend her diligently: ſhe is a wonder.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Have you found ſhe was well delivered:
What, had ſhe a good Mid-wife, is all well?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You are merry Norandine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why weepe you, Lady?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Take the poor Babe along.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Madam 'tis here.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Diſſembling death, why didſt thou let me live
To ſee this change, my greateſt cauſe to grieve? Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena ſecunda.
div.stage: Enter Aſtorius, Caſtriot, Valetta, Gomera, Synnet: Knights, 2 Biſhops, Mountferrat, guarded by Corporall and Souldiers, Abdella, a Gentleman with a cloake, ſword, and Spurres: Gomara.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A tender husband haſt thou ſhew'd thy ſelfe
My deereſt brother, and thy memory
After my life, in brazen Characters,
Shall monumentally be regiſter'd
To ages conſequent, till times running hand,
Beats back the world to undiſtinguiſh'd Chaos,
And on the top of that thy name ſhall ſtand
Freſh, and without decay.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Oh honour'd ſir!
If hope of this, or any bliſſe to come
Could lift my load of griefe off from my ſoule,
Or expiate the treſpaſſe' gainſt my wife,
That in one houres ſuſpition I begat,
I might be won to be a man againe,
And fare like other husbands, ſleepe and eate,
Laugh, and forget my pleaſing penitence;
But till old nature can make ſuch a wife
Againe, I vow ne're to reſume the order
And habits, that to men are neceſſary,
All breath i'le ſpend in ſighes, all ſound in groanes,
And know no company but my waſting moans.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.l: This will be wilfull murder on your ſelf,
Nor like a Chriſtian doe you beare the chance
Which th'inſcrutable will of heaven admits.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: What would you have my weakneſſe doe, that
Suffer'd it ſelfe thus to be practis'd on,
By a damn'd hell-hound, and his agent dam,
The impious mid-wife to obortive birthes,
And cruell inſtrument to his decrees?
By forgery they firſt aſſail'd her life,
Heaven playing with us yet, in that, he wrought
My deereſt friend, the ſervant to her vertue
To combat me, againſt his Miſtreſſe truth.
That yet effectleſſe, this enchanting witch,
Bred banefull jealouſie againſt my Lady,
My moſt immaculate Lady, which ſeiz'd on her
Almoſt to death: Oh yet! not yet content,
She in my hand put (to reſtore her life
As I imagin'd) what did execute
Their devilliſh malice, farther, great with childe,
Was this poore innocent, that too was loſt,
They doubled death upon her, not ſtaying there,
They have done violence unto her Tomb,
Not granting reſt unto her in the grave:
I wiſh Miranda had injoy'd my prize;
For ſure I'm puniſh'd for uſurping her,
Oh what a Tyger is reſiſted Luſt?
How it doth forrage all?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Part of this tale
I grant you true; but 'twas not poyſon given her.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I would it had, we had been farre enough,
If we had been ſo wiſe, and had not now
Stood curtſing for your mercies here.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Beſide,
What is become oth' body? we know not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Peace impudents,
And deere Gomera practiſe patience
As I my ſelf muſt, by ſome meanes at laſt
We ſhall diſſolve this riddle.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Wherefore comes
This villaine in the feſtivall array,
As if he triumph'd for his treacherie?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: That is by our appointment: give us leave,
You ſhall know why a non. Enter Miranda, Norandine, Collona.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: One of the Eſguard.

sp.speaker: Eſg.
sp.l: The Gentlemen are come,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Truyce then a while
With our ſad thoughts; what are you both reſolv'd?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Not I my Lord: your downe right Captain ſtill
Ile live, and ſerve you, not that altogether
I want compunction of conſcience,
I have enough to ſave me, and that's all,
Bar me from drink, and drabs, ev'n hang me too,
You muſt ev'n make your Captaines capons firſt,
I have too much fleſh for this ſpirituall Knighthood,
And therefore do deſire forbearance, ſir,
Till I am older, or more mortifide,
I am too ſound yet.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: What ſay you Miranda?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: With all pure zeale to Heaven, duty to you,
I come to undergo it.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Proceed toth' ceremony.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Before you match with this bright honor'd title,
Admir'd Miranda, pardon what in thought
I ever did tranſgreſſe againſt your vertue,
And may you find more joy with your new bride
Then poor Gomera ere in joyd with his.
But 'twas mine own crime, and I ſuffer for't:
Long wear your dignity, and worthily,
Whilſt I obſcurely in ſome corner vaniſh,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Have ſtronger thoughts, and better, firſt I crave
According to the order of the Court
I may diſpoſe my captives, and the fort,
That with a clean and purified heart
The fittiler I may endue my roabe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Tis granted. Enter Oriana vaild, Ladies, Lucinda, child.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Bring the captives. To your charge
And ſtaid tuition my moſt noble friend;
I then commend this Lady; ſtart not off
A fairer, and a chaſter never liv'd;
By her own choyce you are her Guardian,
For telling her I was to leave my fort,
And to abandon quite all worldly cares.
Her own requeſt was, to Gomeras hands
She might be given in cuſtody, for ſh'ad heard
He was a Gentleman wiſe, and temperate,
Full of humanity to womenkind,
And cauſe he had bin married knew the better
How to entrat a Lady.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What Country woman is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Borne a Greek.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Gomera, 'twill be barbarous to deny
A Lady, that unto your refuge flyes,
And ſeekes to ſhrowd her under vertues wing.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Excuſe me noble ſir; oh think me not
So dull a devill, to forget the loſſe
Of ſuch a matchleſſe wife as I poſſes'd,
And ever to endure the ſight of woman:
Were ſhe the abſtract of her ſex for forme,
The only warehouſe of perfection,
Where there no Roſe, nor Lilly but her Cheek,
No Muſick but her tongue; vertue but hers;
She muſt not reſt near me, my vow is graven,
Here in my heart, irrevocably breath'd
And when I break it,

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.l: This is rudeneſſe Spaniard,
Unſeaſonably you play the Timoniſt,
Put on a diſpoſition is not yours,
Which neither fits you, nor becomes you.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: We cannot force you but we would perſwade.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Beſeech you Sir, no more I am reſolv'd
To forſake Malta, tread a Pilgrimage
To faire Jeruſalem, for my Ladies ſoule,
And will not be diverted.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You muſt beare
This Child along 'we then.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: VVhat Child?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nay then Gomera, thou art injurious,
This child is thine, and this rejected Lady
Thou haſt as often known, as thine own wife,
And this I'le make good on thee, with my ſword.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Thou durſt as well blaſpheme: if ſuch a ſcandall
(I crave the rights due to a Gentleman)
Women unvaile.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Will you refuſe me yet?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: My wife!

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: My ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Some body, thank Heaven
I cannot ſpeak.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: All praiſe be ever given:

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: This ſaves our lives, yet would ſhe had bin dead;
The very ſight of her afflicts me more
Then fear of puniſhment, or my diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: How came you to the Temple?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, to do
My poor devotions, and to offer thanks
For ſcaping a temptation ne'r perform'd
VVith this faire virgin. I reſtore a wife
Earth cannot paralell: and buſie nature
If thou wilt ſtill make women, but remember
To work 'em by this ſampler; take heed ſir,
Henceforth you never doubt ſir.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: VVhen I do
Death take me ſodainly.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: To encreaſe your happineſſe
To your beſt wife, take this addition.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Alack, my poor knave.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: The confeſſion
The Moor made 't ſeemes was truth.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Mary was it ſir; the only truth that ever iſſud out of hell, which her black jawes reſemble; a plague o' your bacon-face, you muſt be giving drinks with a ven|gance; ah thou branded bitch: do'ye ſtare, gogles, I hope to make winter bootes o' thy hide yet, ſhe feares not damning: hell fire cannot parch her blacker then ſhe is: do'ye grin, chimney ſweeper.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: VVhat is't Mranda?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: That you would pleaſe Lucinda might attend you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: That ſuit ſir, I conſent not to.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My husband?
My deereſt Angelo?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: More liggam bobs; is not this the fellow that ſwom
Like a duck to th'ſhoare in our ſea-ſervice?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The very ſame, do not you know me now ſir,
My name is Angelo, though Colonna vaild it,
Your Countryman, and kinſman born in Florence,
VVho from the neighbour Iſland here of Goza
VVhas captive lead, in that unfortunate day
VVhen the Turk bore with him three thouſand ſoules;
Since in Conſtantinople have I liv'd
VVhere I beheld this Turkiſh Damoſell firſt.
A tedious ſuitor was I for her love,
And pittying ſuch a beauteous caſe ſhould hide
A ſoule prophan'd with infidelity,
I labourd her converſion with my love,
And doubly won her, to faire faith her ſoule
She firſt betroth'd, and then her faith to me,
But fearfull there to conſummate this contract
VVe fled, and in that flight were tane againe
By thoſe ſame Gallies, fore Valletta fought.
Since in your ſervice I attended her,
VVhere, what I ſaw, and heard, hath joy'd me more
Then all my paſt afflictions greiv'd before.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Wonders crown wonders: take thy wife Miranda.
Be henceforth called our Malta's better angell,
And thou her evill Mountferrat.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Wee'l call him Cacodemon, with his block gib there, his Succuba, his devils ſeed, his ſpawn of Phlege|ton, that o' my conſcience was bred o' the ſpume of Cocitus; do ye ſnarle you black jill? ſhe looks lie the Picture of America.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why ſtay we now.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This laſt petition to the Court,
I may bequeath the keeping of my Fort
To this my kinſman, toward the maintenance
Of him, and his faire vertuous wife; diſcreet,
Loyall, and valiant I dare give him you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You muſt not ask in vaine, ſir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: My beſt thanks
To you my noble Cozen, and my ſervice
To the whole Court; may I deſerve this bounty.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Proceed to th'ceremony, one of our Eſguard
Degrade Mountferrat firſt

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I will not ſue
For mercy, 'twere in vaine; fortune thy worſt. Muſick

div.stage: An altar diſcovered, with Tapers, and a book on it. The two Biſhops ſtand on each ſide of it Mountferrat as the Song is ſinging aſcends up the altar.

sp.l: See ſee, the ſtaine of honor, vertues foe,
Of Virgins fair fames, the foule overthrow,
That broken hath his oath of chaſtity
Diſhonor'd much this holy dignity,
Off with his Roab, expell him forth this place,
Whilſt we rejoyce, and ſing at his diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Since by thy actions thou haſt made thy ſelf
Unworthy of that worthy ſigne thou wear●ſt,
And of our ſacred order, into which
For former vertues, we receiv'd thee firſt,
According to our Statutes, Ordinances,
For praiſe unto the good, a terror to
The bad, and an example to all men;
We here deprive thee of our habit, and
Declare thee unworthy our ſociety,
From which we do expell thee, as a rotten
Corrupted, and contagious member.

sp.speaker: Eſq.
sp.l: Uſing th'authority th'Superiour
Hath given unto me, I unty this knot,
And take from thee the pleaſing yoak of heaven:
We take from off thy breaſt this holy croſſe,
Which thou haſt made thy burthen, not thy prop;
Thy ſpurs we ſpoile thee off, eleaving thy heeles
Bare of thy honour, that have kick'd againſt
Our orders precepts: next we reave thy ſword,
And give thee armeleſſe to thy enemies,
For being foe to goodneſſe, and to God,
Laſt, 'bout thy ſtiff neck, we this halter hang,
And leave thee to the mercy of the Court.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Inveſt Miranda.
Faire child of vertue, honors bloome
That here with burning zeale doſt come
With joy to ask the white croſſe cloak,
And yeild unto this pleaſing yoake
That being yong, vowes chaſtity,
And chooſeſt wilfull poverty;
As this flame mounts, ſo mount thy zeale, thy glory
Riſe paſt the Stars, and fix in Heaven thy ſtory.

sp.speaker: 1. Biſh.
sp.l: What crave you gentle ſir?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Humble admittance
To be a brother of the holy Hoſpitall
Of great Jeruſalem.

sp.speaker: 2. Biſh.
sp.l: Breath out your vow.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: To heaven and all the bench of Saints above
Whoſe ſuccour I implore t'enhable me,
I vow henceforth a chaſte life, not to enjoy
Any thing proper to my ſelf; obedience
To my ſuperiours, whom Religion,
And Heaven ſhall give me: ever to defend
The vertuous fame of Ladies, and to oppugne
Even unto death the Chriſtian enemy,
This do I vow to accompliſh.

sp.speaker: Eſq.
sp.l: Who can tell,
H'as he made other vow, or promis'd marriage
To any one, or is in ſervitude?

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: He's free from all theſe.

sp.speaker: 1. Biſh.
sp.l: Put on his ſpurs, and girt him with the ſword,
The ſcourge of infidels, and tipes of ſpeed.
Buildſt thy faith on this

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: On him that di'd
On ſuch a ſacred figure, for our ſins.

sp.speaker: 2. Biſh.
sp.l: Here, then we fix it on thy left ſide, for
Thy encreaſe of faith, Chriſtian defence, and ſervice
To th'poor, and thus near to thy heart we plant it
That thou maiſt love it even with all thy heart,
With thy right hand protect, preſerve it whole,
For if thou fighting 'gainſt heavens enemies
Shall fly away, abandoning the croſſe
The Enſigne of thy holy Generall,
With ſhame thou juſtly ſhalt be rob'd of it
Chas'd from our company, and cut away
As an infectious putrified limb.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I aske no favour.

sp.speaker: 1 Biſh.
sp.l: Then receive the yoak
Of him that makes it ſweet, and light, in which
Thy ſoule find her eternall reſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Moſt welcome.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Welcome, our noble brother.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Break up the Court; Mountferrat, though your deeds
Conſpiring 'gainſt the lives of innocents
Hath forfeited your own, we will not ſtaine
Our white Croſſe with your blood: your doom is then
To marry this coagent of your miſchiefes
Which done, we baniſh you the continent,
If either, after three dayes here be found
The hand of Law, layes hold upon your lives.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Away French ſtallion, now you have a Barbary mare of your own, go leap her, and engender young devillings.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: VVe will find ſomething, noble Norandine
To quit your merit: ſo to civill feaſts,
According to our cuſtomes; and all pray
The dew of grace, bleſſe our new Knight to day. Exeunt.
